Text

﻿ [ [Northanger Abbey]1-northanger abbey by [Jane Austen]72-jane austen ( 1803 ) ]

CHAPTER 1

[No one who had ever seen [Catherine Morland]73-catherine in [her]180-her infancy]179-no one who had ever seen catherine morland in her infancy would have supposed [her]180-her born to be [an heroine]181-an heroine . [Her]180-her situation in life , the character of [[her]180-her father]182-her father and [mother]183-mother , [her]180-her own person and disposition , were all equally against [her]180-her . [[Her]180-her father]182-her father was [a clergyman]185-a clergyman , without being neglected , or poor , and [a very respectable man]186-a very respectable man , though [his]182-her father name was [Richard]74-captain tilney — and [he]182-her father had never been handsome . [He]182-her father had a considerable independence besides two good livings — and [he]182-her father was not in the least addicted to locking up [[his]182-her father daughters]187-his daughters . [[Her]180-her mother]188-her mother was [a woman of useful plain sense , with a good temper , and , what is more remarkable , with a good constitution]189-a woman of useful plain sense , with a good temper , and , what is more remarkable , with a good constitution . [She]188-her mother had [three sons]190-three sons before [Catherine]73-catherine was born ; and instead of dying in bringing the latter into [the world]191-the world , as [anybody]192-anybody might expect , [she]188-her mother still lived on — lived to have [six children]193-six children more — to see [them]193-six children growing up around [her]188-her mother , and to enjoy excellent health [herself]188-her mother . [A family of ten children]194-a family of ten children will be always called [a fine family]195-a fine family , where there are heads and arms and legs enough for the number ; but [the Morlands]75-the morlands had little other right to the word , for [they]75-the morlands were in general very plain , and [Catherine]73-catherine , for many years of [her]180-her life , as plain as any . [She]180-her had a thin awkward figure , a sallow skin without colour , dark lank hair , and strong features — so much for [her]180-her person ; and not less unpropitious for heroism seemed [her]180-her mind . [She]180-her was fond of [all boys]196-all boys ’ plays , and greatly preferred cricket not merely to dolls , but to the more heroic enjoyments of infancy , nursing a dormouse , feeding a canary - bird , or watering a rose - bush . Indeed [she]180-her had no taste for [a garden]197-a garden ; and if [she]180-her gathered flowers at all , it was chiefly for the pleasure of mischief — at least so it was conjectured from [her]180-her always preferring those which [she]180-her was forbidden to take . Such were [her]180-her propensities — [her]180-her abilities were quite as extraordinary . [She]180-her never could learn or understand anything before [she]180-her was taught ; and sometimes not even then , for [she]180-her was often inattentive , and occasionally stupid . [[Her]180-her mother]188-her mother was three months in teaching [her]180-her only to repeat the “ Beggar ’s Petition ”[188-her mother] ; and after all , [[her]180-her next sister]199-her next sister , [Sally]76-sarah , could say it better than [she]180-her did . Not that [Catherine]73-catherine was always stupid — by no means ; [she]180-her learnt the fable of “ [The Hare]77-the hare and [Many Friends]2178-many friends ”[188-her mother] as quickly as [any girl in [England]2-england]200-any girl in england . [[Her]180-her mother]188-her mother wished [her]180-her to learn music ; and [Catherine]73-catherine was sure [she]180-her should like it , for [she]180-her was very fond of tinkling the keys of the old forlorn spinnet ; so , at eight years old [she]180-her began . [She]180-her learnt a year , and could not bear it ; and [Mrs. Morland]78-mrs. morland , who did not insist on [[her]78-mrs. morland daughters]202-her daughters being accomplished in spite of incapacity or distaste , allowed [her]180-her to leave off . The day which dismissed [the music - master]203-the music - master was one of the happiest of [Catherine]73-catherine ’s life . [Her]180-her taste for drawing was not superior ; though whenever [she]180-her could obtain the outside of a letter from [[her]180-her mother]188-her mother or seize upon any other odd piece of paper , [she]180-her did what [she]180-her could in that way , by drawing [houses]205-houses and trees , hens and chickens , all very much like one another . Writing and accounts [she]180-her was taught by [[her]180-her father]182-her father ; French by [[her]180-her mother]188-her mother : [her]180-her proficiency in either was not remarkable , and [she]180-her shirked [her]180-her lessons in both whenever [she]180-her could . What a strange , unaccountable character!—for with all these symptoms of profligacy at ten years old , [she]180-her had neither a bad heart nor a bad temper , was seldom stubborn , scarcely ever quarrelsome , and very kind to [the little ones]208-the little ones , with few interruptions of tyranny ; [she]180-her was moreover noisy and wild , hated confinement and cleanliness , and loved nothing so well in [the world]191-the world as rolling down [the green slope]210-the green slope at the back of [the house]211-the house .

Such was [Catherine Morland]73-catherine at ten . At fifteen , appearances were mending ; [she]180-her began to curl [her]180-her hair and long for balls ; [her]180-her complexion improved , [her]180-her features were softened by plumpness and colour , [her]180-her eyes gained more animation , and [her]180-her figure more consequence . [Her]180-her love of dirt gave way to an inclination for finery , and [she]180-her grew clean as [she]180-her grew smart ; [she]180-her had now the pleasure of sometimes hearing [[her]180-her father]182-her father and [mother]183-mother remark on [her]180-her personal improvement . “ [Catherine]73-catherine grows quite [a good - looking girl]2179-a good - looking girl — [she]180-her is almost pretty to - day , ”[183-mother] were words which caught [her]180-her ears now and then ; and how welcome were the sounds ! to look _ almost _ pretty is an acquisition of higher delight to [a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of]214-a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of [her]214-a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of life than a beauty from [her]214-a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of cradle can ever receive .

[Mrs. Morland]78-mrs. morland was [a very good woman]215-a very good woman , and wished to see [[her]78-mrs. morland children]216-her children everything [they]216-her children ought to be ; but [her]78-mrs. morland time was so much occupied in lying - in and teaching [the little ones]208-the little ones , that [[her]78-mrs. morland elder daughters]218-her elder daughters were inevitably left to shift for [themselves]218-her elder daughters ; and it was not very wonderful that [Catherine]73-catherine , who had by nature nothing heroic about [her]180-her , should prefer cricket , baseball , riding on horseback , and running about [the country]219-the country at the age of fourteen , to books — or at least books of information — for , provided that nothing like useful knowledge could be gained from [them]220-them , provided they were all story and no reflection , [she]180-her had never any objection to books at all . But from fifteen to seventeen [she]180-her was in training for [a heroine]221-a heroine ; [she]180-her read all such works as [heroines]222-heroines must read to supply [their]222-heroines memories with those quotations which are so serviceable and so soothing in the vicissitudes of [their]222-heroines eventful lives .

From [Pope]79-pope , [she]180-her learnt to censure [those who

“ bear about the mockery of woe]2180-those who “ bear about the mockery of woe . ”[2180-those who “ bear about the mockery of woe]

From [Gray]80-gray , that

“ Many a flower is born to blush unseen , “[81-thomson] And waste its fragrance on the desert air . ”[180-her]

From [Thomson]81-thomson , that —

“ It is a delightful task “[81-thomson] To teach [the young idea how to shoot . ”]2181-the young idea how to shoot . ”[81-thomson]

And from [Shakespeare]82-shakespeare [she]180-her gained a great store of information — amongst the rest , that —

“ Trifles light as air , “[81-thomson] Are , to the jealous , confirmation strong , “ As proofs of Holy Writ . ”[81-thomson]

That

“ [The poor beetle]2182-the poor beetle , which [we]2183-we tread upon , “[82-shakespeare] In corporal sufferance feels a pang as great “ As when a giant dies . ”[82-shakespeare]

And that [a young woman in love]223-a young woman in love always looks —

“ like Patience on a monument “[223-a young woman in love] Smiling at Grief . ”[223-a young woman in love]

So far [her]180-her improvement was sufficient — and in many other points [she]180-her came on exceedingly well ; for though [she]180-her could not write sonnets , [she]180-her brought [herself]180-her to read them ; and though there seemed no chance of [her]180-her throwing [a whole party]224-a whole party into raptures by a prelude on the pianoforte , of [her]180-her own composition , [she]180-her could listen to [other people]225-other people ’s performance with very little fatigue . [Her]180-her greatest deficiency was in the pencil — [she]180-her had no notion of drawing — not enough even to attempt a sketch of [[her]180-her lover]226-her lover ’s profile , that [she]180-her might be detected in the design . There [she]180-her fell miserably short of the true heroic height . At present [she]180-her did not know [her]180-her own poverty , for [she]180-her had [no lover]227-no lover to portray . [She]180-her had reached the age of seventeen , without having seen [one amiable youth who could call forth [her]180-her sensibility , without having inspired one real passion]228-one amiable youth who could call forth her sensibility , without having inspired one real passion , and without having excited even any admiration but what was very moderate and very transient . This was strange indeed ! but strange things may be generally accounted for if [their]229-their cause be fairly searched out . There was not [one lord in [the neighbourhood]231-the neighbourhood]230-one lord in the neighbourhood ; no — not even [a baronet]232-a baronet . There was [not one family among [their]229-their acquaintance who had reared and supported [a boy accidentally found at [their]229-their door]234-a boy accidentally found at their door]233-not one family among their acquaintance who had reared and supported a boy accidentally found at their door — [not one young man whose origin was unknown . [[Her]180-her father]182-her father had [no ward]237-no ward , and [the squire of [the parish]239-the parish]238-the squire of the parish no [children]240-children]235-not one young man whose origin was unknown . her father had no ward , and the squire of the parish no children .

But when [a young lady]241-a young lady is to be [a heroine]221-a heroine , the perverseness of [forty surrounding families]243-forty surrounding families can not prevent [her]241-a young lady . Something must and will happen to throw [a hero]244-a hero in [her]241-a young lady way .

[Mr. Allen]83-mr. allen , who owned [the chief of [the property about [Fullerton]3-fullerton]246-the property about fullerton]245-the chief of the property about fullerton , [the village in [Wiltshire]4-wiltshire where [the Morlands]75-the morlands lived]247-the village in wiltshire where the morlands lived , was ordered to [Bath]5-bath for the benefit of a gouty constitution — and [[his]83-mr. allen lady]248-his lady , [a good - humoured woman]249-a good - humoured woman , fond of [Miss Morland]84-miss morland , and probably aware that if adventures will not befall [a young lady in [[her]241-a young lady [own village]252-own village]251-her own village]250-a young lady in her own village , [she]241-a young lady must seek [them]253-them abroad , invited [her]241-a young lady to go with [them]253-them . [Mr.]254-mr. and [Mrs. Morland]78-mrs. morland were all compliance , and [Catherine]73-catherine all happiness .

CHAPTER 2

In addition to what has been already said of [Catherine Morland]73-catherine ’s personal and mental endowments , when about to be launched into all the difficulties and dangers of a six weeks ’ residence in [Bath]5-bath , it may be stated , for [the reader]255-the reader ’s more certain information , lest the following pages should otherwise fail of giving any idea of what [her]84-miss morland character is meant to be , that [her]84-miss morland heart was affectionate ; [her]84-miss morland disposition cheerful and open , without conceit or affectation of any kind — [her]84-miss morland manners just removed from the awkwardness and shyness of [a girl]256-a girl ; [her]84-miss morland person pleasing , and , when in good looks , pretty — and [her]84-miss morland mind about as ignorant and uninformed as the female mind at seventeen usually is .

When the hour of departure drew near , the maternal anxiety of [Mrs. Morland]78-mrs. morland will be naturally supposed to be most severe . A thousand alarming presentiments of evil to [[her]78-mrs. morland beloved]257-her beloved [Catherine]73-catherine from this terrific separation must oppress [her]78-mrs. morland heart with sadness , and drown [her]78-mrs. morland in tears for the last day or two of [their]258-their being together ; and advice of the most important and applicable nature must of course flow from [her]78-mrs. morland wise lips in [their]258-their parting conference in [[her]78-mrs. morland closet]259-her closet . Cautions against the violence of [such noblemen]260-such noblemen and [baronets]261-baronets as delight in forcing [young ladies]262-young ladies away to [some remote farm - house]263-some remote farm - house , must , at such a moment , relieve the fulness of [her]78-mrs. morland heart . Who would not think so ? But [Mrs. Morland]78-mrs. morland knew so little of [lords]264-lords and [baronets]261-baronets , that [she]78-mrs. morland entertained no notion of [their]258-their general mischievousness , and was wholly unsuspicious of danger to [[her]78-mrs. morland daughter]266-her daughter from [their]258-their machinations . [Her]78-mrs. morland cautions were confined to the following points . “ [I]78-mrs. morland beg , [Catherine]73-catherine , [you]73-catherine will always wrap [yourself]73-catherine up very warm about the throat , when [you]73-catherine come from [the Rooms]2184-the rooms at night ; and [I]78-mrs. morland wish [you]73-catherine would try to keep some account of the money [you]73-catherine spend ; [I]78-mrs. morland will give [you]73-catherine this little book on purpose . ”[78-mrs. morland]

[Sally]76-sarah , or rather [Sarah]76-sarah ( for what [young lady of common gentility]267-young lady of common gentility will reach the age of sixteen without altering [her]267-young lady of common gentility name as far as [she]267-young lady of common gentility can ? ) , must from situation be at this time [the intimate friend and confidante of [[her]78-mrs. morland sister]269-her sister]268-the intimate friend and confidante of her sister . It is remarkable , however , that [she]78-mrs. morland neither insisted on [Catherine]73-catherine ’s writing by every post , nor exacted [her]78-mrs. morland promise of transmitting the character of [every new acquaintance]270-every new acquaintance , nor a detail of every interesting conversation that [Bath]5-bath might produce . Everything indeed relative to this important journey was done , on the part of [the Morlands]75-the morlands , with a degree of moderation and composure , which seemed rather consistent with the common feelings of common life , than with the refined susceptibilities , the tender emotions which the first separation of [a heroine]221-a heroine from [[her]221-a heroine family]272-her family ought always to excite . [[Her]78-mrs. morland father]182-her father , instead of giving [her]78-mrs. morland an unlimited order on [[his]182-her father banker]274-his banker , or even putting an hundred pounds bank - bill into [her]78-mrs. morland hands , gave [her]78-mrs. morland only ten guineas , and promised [her]78-mrs. morland more when [she]78-mrs. morland wanted it .

Under these unpromising auspices , the parting took place , and the journey began . It was performed with suitable quietness and uneventful safety . [Neither robbers]275-neither robbers nor [tempests]276-tempests befriended [them]277-them , nor one lucky overturn to introduce [them]277-them to [the hero]278-the hero . Nothing more alarming occurred than a fear , on [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen ’s side , of having once left [her]78-mrs. morland clogs behind [her]78-mrs. morland at [an inn]279-an inn , and that fortunately proved to be groundless .

[They]277-them arrived at [Bath]5-bath . [Catherine]73-catherine was all eager delight — [her]78-mrs. morland eyes were [here]280-here , there , everywhere , as [they]277-them approached [[its]5-bath fine and striking environs]281-its fine and striking environs , and afterwards drove through [those streets]282-those streets which conducted [them]277-them to [the hotel]283-the hotel . [She]78-mrs. morland was come to be happy , and [she]78-mrs. morland felt happy already .

[They]277-them were soon settled in [comfortable lodgings in [Pulteney Street]7-pulteney street]284-comfortable lodgings in pulteney street .

It is now expedient to give some description of [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen , that [the reader]255-the reader may be able to judge in what manner [her]78-mrs. morland actions will hereafter tend to promote the general distress of the work , and how [she]78-mrs. morland will , probably , contribute to reduce poor [Catherine]73-catherine to all the desperate wretchedness of which a last volume is capable — whether by [her]78-mrs. morland imprudence , vulgarity , or jealousy — whether by intercepting [her]78-mrs. morland letters , ruining [her]78-mrs. morland character , or turning [her]78-mrs. morland out of doors .

[Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen was [one of that numerous class of females , whose society can raise no other emotion than surprise at there being [any men in [the world]191-the world who could like [them]277-them well enough to marry [them]277-them]287-any men in the world who could like them well enough to marry them]286-one of that numerous class of females , whose society can raise no other emotion than surprise at there being any men in the world who could like them well enough to marry them . [She]78-mrs. morland had neither beauty , genius , accomplishment , nor manner . The air of [a gentlewoman]289-a gentlewoman , a great deal of quiet , inactive good temper , and a trifling turn of mind were all that could account for [her]78-mrs. morland being the choice of [a sensible , intelligent man like [Mr. Allen]83-mr. allen]290-a sensible , intelligent man like mr. allen . In one respect [she]78-mrs. morland was admirably fitted to introduce [a young lady]241-a young lady into public , being as fond of going everywhere and seeing everything [herself]78-mrs. morland as [any young lady]292-any young lady could be . Dress was [her]78-mrs. morland passion . [She]78-mrs. morland had a most harmless delight in being fine ; and [[our]293-our heroine]294-our heroine ’s entree into life could not take place till after three or four days had been spent in learning what was mostly worn , and [[her]78-mrs. morland chaperon]295-her chaperon was provided with a dress of the newest fashion . [Catherine]73-catherine too made some purchases [herself]73-catherine , and when all these matters were arranged , the important evening came which was to usher [her]78-mrs. morland into [the Upper Rooms]296-the upper rooms . [Her]78-mrs. morland hair was cut and dressed by the best hand , [her]78-mrs. morland clothes put on with care , and both [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen and [[her]78-mrs. morland maid]297-her maid declared [she]78-mrs. morland looked quite as [she]78-mrs. morland should do . With such encouragement , [Catherine]73-catherine hoped at least to pass uncensured through [the crowd]298-the crowd . As for admiration , it was always very welcome when it came , but [she]78-mrs. morland did not depend on it .

[Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen was so long in dressing that [they]299-they did not enter [the ballroom]300-the ballroom till late . The season was full , [the room]301-the room crowded , and [the two ladies]302-the two ladies squeezed in as well as [they]299-they could . As for [Mr. Allen]83-mr. allen , [he]83-mr. allen repaired directly to [the card - room]303-the card - room , and left [them]299-they to enjoy a mob by [themselves]299-they . With more care for the safety of [her]78-mrs. morland new gown than for the comfort of [her]78-mrs. morland protégée , [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen made [her]78-mrs. morland way through the throng of [men by the door]304-men by the door , as swiftly as the necessary caution would allow ; [Catherine]73-catherine , however , kept close at [her]78-mrs. morland side , and linked [her]78-mrs. morland arm too firmly within [[her]78-mrs. morland friend]305-her friend ’s to be torn asunder by any common effort of [a struggling assembly]306-a struggling assembly . But to [her]78-mrs. morland utter amazement [she]78-mrs. morland found that to proceed along [the room]301-the room was by no means the way to disengage [themselves]299-they from [the crowd]298-the crowd ; it seemed rather to increase as [they]299-they went on , whereas [she]78-mrs. morland had imagined that when once fairly within the door , [they]299-they should easily find seats and be able to watch the dances with perfect convenience . But this was far from being the case , and though by unwearied diligence [they]299-they gained even the top of [the room]301-the room , [their]299-they situation was just the same ; [they]299-they saw nothing of [the dancers]310-the dancers but the high feathers of [some of [the ladies]312-the ladies]311-some of the ladies . Still [they]299-they moved on — something better was yet in view ; and by a continued exertion of strength and ingenuity [they]299-they found [themselves]299-they at last in the passage behind the highest bench . Here there was something less of [crowd]313-crowd than below ; and hence [Miss Morland]84-miss morland had a comprehensive view of [all the company beneath [her]84-miss morland]314-all the company beneath her , and of all the dangers of [her]84-miss morland late passage through [them]314-all the company beneath her . It was a splendid sight , and [she]84-miss morland began , for the first time that evening , to feel [herself]84-miss morland at a ball : [she]84-miss morland longed to dance , but [she]84-miss morland had not an acquaintance in [the room]301-the room . [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen did all that [she]84-miss morland could do in such a case by saying very placidly , every now and then , “ [I]84-miss morland wish [you]73-catherine could dance , [[my]84-miss morland dear]2185-my dear — [I]84-miss morland wish [you]73-catherine could get [a partner]2186-a partner . ”[84-miss morland] For some time [[her]84-miss morland young friend]316-her young friend felt obliged to [her]84-miss morland for these wishes ; but they were repeated so often , and proved so totally ineffectual , that [Catherine]73-catherine grew tired at last , and would thank [her]316-her young friend no more .

[They]317-we were not long able , however , to enjoy the repose of the eminence [they]317-we had so laboriously gained . [Everybody]318-everybody was shortly in motion for tea , and [they]318-everybody must squeeze out like [the rest]319-the rest . [Catherine]73-catherine began to feel something of disappointment — [she]84-miss morland was tired of being continually pressed against by [people]320-people , [the generality of whose faces possessed nothing to interest]321-the generality of whose faces possessed nothing to interest , and with all of whom [she]84-miss morland was so wholly unacquainted that [she]84-miss morland could not relieve the irksomeness of imprisonment by the exchange of a syllable with [any of [[her]84-miss morland fellow captives]323-her fellow captives]322-any of her fellow captives ; and when at last arrived in [the tea - room]324-the tea - room , [she]84-miss morland felt yet more the awkwardness of having [no party]325-no party to join , [no acquaintance]326-no acquaintance to claim , [no gentleman]327-no gentleman to assist [them]317-we . [They]317-we saw nothing of [Mr. Allen]83-mr. allen ; and after looking about [them]317-we in vain for a more eligible situation , were obliged to sit down at the end of a table , at which [a large party]328-a large party were already placed , without having anything to do there , or [anybody to speak to]329-anybody to speak to , except [each other]330-each other .

[Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen congratulated [herself]86-mrs. allen , as soon as [they]317-we were seated , on having preserved [her]84-miss morland gown from injury . “ It would have been very shocking to have it torn , ”[84-miss morland] said [she]84-miss morland , “ would not it ? It is such a delicate muslin . For [my]84-miss morland part [I]84-miss morland have not seen anything [I]84-miss morland like so well in [the whole room]2187-the whole room , [I]84-miss morland assure [you]2188-you . ”[84-miss morland]

“ How uncomfortable it is , ”[73-catherine] whispered [Catherine]73-catherine , “ not to have [a single acquaintance]2189-a single acquaintance [here]280-here ! ”[73-catherine]

“ Yes , [[my]86-mrs. allen dear]2185-my dear , ”[86-mrs. allen] replied [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen , with perfect serenity , “ it is very uncomfortable indeed . ”[86-mrs. allen]

“ What shall [we]317-we do ? [The gentlemen]2192-the gentlemen and [ladies at this table]2193-ladies at this table look as if [they]2192-the gentlemen wondered why [we]317-we came [here]280-here — [we]317-we seem forcing [ourselves]317-we into [their]2192-the gentlemen party . ”[73-catherine]

“ Aye , so [we]317-we do . That is very disagreeable . [I]86-mrs. allen wish [we]317-we had [a large acquaintance]2195-a large acquaintance here . ”[86-mrs. allen]

“ [I]73-catherine wish [we]317-we had _ any;_—it would be [somebody]2196-somebody to go to . ”[73-catherine]

“ Very true , [[my]86-mrs. allen dear]2185-my dear ; and if [we]317-we knew [anybody]192-anybody [we]317-we would join [them]192-anybody directly . [The Skinners]2199-the skinners were here last year — [I]86-mrs. allen wish [they]2199-the skinners were [here]280-here now . ”[86-mrs. allen]

“ Had not [we]317-we better go away as it is ? Here are no tea - things for [us]317-we , [you]2185-my dear see . ”[73-catherine]

“ No more there are , indeed . How very provoking ! but [I]86-mrs. allen think [we]317-we had better sit still , for [one]2201-one gets so tumbled in [such a crowd]2202-such a crowd ! how is [my]86-mrs. allen head , [[my]86-mrs. allen dear]2185-my dear ? [Somebody]2196-somebody gave [me]86-mrs. allen a push that has hurt it , [I]86-mrs. allen am afraid . ”[86-mrs. allen]

“ No , indeed , it looks very nice . But , [dear Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen , are [you]86-mrs. allen sure there is [[nobody]2205-nobody [you]86-mrs. allen know in all this multitude of [people]320-people]2206-nobody you know in all this multitude of people ? [I]73-catherine think [you]86-mrs. allen _ must _ know [somebody]2196-somebody . ”[73-catherine]

“ [I]86-mrs. allen do n’t , upon [my]86-mrs. allen word — [I]86-mrs. allen wish [I]86-mrs. allen did . [I]86-mrs. allen should be so glad to have [you]86-mrs. allen dance . There goes [a strange - looking woman]2210-a strange - looking woman ! what an odd gown [she]2210-a strange - looking woman has got on ! how old - fashioned it is ! look at the back . ”[86-mrs. allen]

After some time [they]331-they received an offer of tea from [one of [[their]331-they neighbours]333-their neighbours]332-one of their neighbours ; it was thankfully accepted , and this introduced a light conversation with [the gentleman who offered it]334-the gentleman who offered it , which was the only time that [anybody]192-anybody spoke to [them]331-they during the evening , till [they]331-they were discovered and joined by [Mr. Allen]83-mr. allen when the dance was over .

“ Well , [Miss Morland]84-miss morland , ”[83-mr. allen] said [he]83-mr. allen , directly , “ [I]83-mr. allen hope [you]336-you have had an agreeable ball . ”[83-mr. allen]

“ Very agreeable indeed , ”[336-you] [she]336-you replied , vainly endeavouring to hide a great yawn .

“ [I]337-his wife wish [she]2210-a strange - looking woman had been able to dance , ”[337-his wife] said [[his]83-mr. allen wife]337-his wife ; “ [I]337-his wife wish [we]331-they could have got [a partner]2186-a partner for [her]2210-a strange - looking woman . [I]337-his wife have been saying how glad [I]337-his wife should be if [the Skinners]87-the skinners were here this winter instead of last ; or if [the Parrys]88-the parrys had come , as [they]87-the skinners talked of once , [she]2210-a strange - looking woman might have danced with [George Parry]89-george . “ [We]2213-we shall do better another evening [I]83-mr. allen hope , ”[83-mr. allen] was [Mr. Allen]83-mr. allen ’s consolation .

[The company]338-the company began to disperse when the dancing was over — enough to leave space for [the remainder]339-the remainder to walk about in some comfort ; and now was the time for [a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening , to be noticed and admired . Every five minutes , by removing [some of [the crowd]298-the crowd]341-some of the crowd , gave greater openings for [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening charms . [She]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening was now seen by [many young men who had not been near [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening before]343-many young men who had not been near her before . [Not one]344-not one , however , started with rapturous wonder on beholding [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening , no whisper of eager inquiry ran round [the room]301-the room , nor was [she]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening once called [a divinity]346-a divinity by [anybody]192-anybody . Yet [Catherine]73-catherine was in very good looks , and had [the company]338-the company only seen [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening three years before , [they]338-the company would _ now _ have thought [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening exceedingly handsome .

[She]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening _ was _ looked at , however , and with some admiration ; for , in [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening own hearing , [two gentlemen]349-two gentlemen pronounced [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening to be [a pretty girl]350-a pretty girl . Such words had [their]349-two gentlemen due effect ; [she]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening immediately thought the evening pleasanter than [she]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening had found it before — [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening humble vanity was contented — [she]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening felt more obliged to [the two young men]351-the two young men for this simple praise than [a true quality heroine]352-a true quality heroine would have been for fifteen sonnets in celebration of [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening charms , and went to [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening chair in good humour with [everybody]318-everybody , and perfectly satisfied with [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening share of public attention .

CHAPTER 3

Every morning now brought its regular duties — [shops]354-shops were to be visited ; [some new part of [the town]356-the town]355-some new part of the town to be looked at ; and [the Pump - room]357-the pump - room to be attended , where [they]349-two gentlemen paraded up and down for an hour , looking at [everybody]318-everybody and speaking to [no one]359-no one . The wish of [a numerous acquaintance in [Bath]5-bath]360-a numerous acquaintance in bath was still uppermost with [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen , and [she]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening repeated it after every fresh proof , which every morning brought , of [her]340-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening knowing [nobody]2205-nobody at all .

[They]349-two gentlemen made [their]349-two gentlemen appearance in [the Lower Rooms]362-the lower rooms ; and here fortune was more favourable to [[our]363-our heroine]294-our heroine . [The master of the ceremonies]365-the master of the ceremonies introduced to [her]294-our heroine [a very gentleman - like young man as [a partner]2186-a partner]366-a very gentleman - like young man as a partner ; [his]366-a very gentleman - like young man as a partner name was [Tilney]90-miss tilney . [He]366-a very gentleman - like young man as a partner seemed to be about four or five and twenty , was rather tall , had a pleasing countenance , a very intelligent and lively eye , and , if not quite handsome , was very near it . [His]366-a very gentleman - like young man as a partner address was good , and [Catherine]73-catherine felt [herself]73-catherine in high luck . There was little leisure for speaking while [they]349-two gentlemen danced ; but when [they]349-two gentlemen were seated at tea , [she]294-our heroine found [him]366-a very gentleman - like young man as a partner as agreeable as [she]294-our heroine had already given [him]366-a very gentleman - like young man as a partner credit for being . [He]366-a very gentleman - like young man as a partner talked with fluency and spirit — and there was an archness and pleasantry in [his]366-a very gentleman - like young man as a partner manner which interested , though it was hardly understood by [her]294-our heroine . After chatting some time on such matters as naturally arose from the objects around [them]349-two gentlemen , [he]366-a very gentleman - like young man as a partner suddenly addressed [her]294-our heroine with—“I have hitherto been very remiss , [madam]2214-madam , in the proper attentions of [a partner here]2215-a partner here ; [I]368-i have not yet asked [you]2214-madam how long [you]2214-madam have been in Bath ; whether [you]2214-madam were ever [here]280-here before ; whether [you]2214-madam have been at [the Upper Rooms]296-the upper rooms , [the theatre]2218-the theatre , and [the concert]2219-the concert ; and how [you]2214-madam like [the place]2220-the place altogether . [I]368-i have been very negligent — but are [you]2214-madam now at leisure to satisfy [me]368-i in these particulars ? If [you]2214-madam are [I]368-i will begin directly . ”[368-i]

“ [You]2214-madam need not give [yourself]2214-madam that trouble , [sir]2221-sir . ”[368-i]

“ No trouble , [I]368-i assure [you]2214-madam , [madam]2214-madam . ”[368-i] Then forming [his]368-i features into a set smile , and affectedly softening [his]368-i voice , [he]368-i added , with a simpering air , “ Have [you]2214-madam been long in [Bath]5-bath , [madam]2214-madam ? ”[368-i]

“ About a week , [sir]2221-sir , ”[73-catherine] replied [Catherine]73-catherine , trying not to laugh .

“ Really ! ”[368-i] with affected astonishment .

“ Why should [you]2214-madam be surprised , [sir]2221-sir ? ”[368-i]

“ Why , indeed ! ”[368-i] said [he]368-i , in [his]368-i natural tone . “ But some emotion must appear to be raised by [your]2214-madam reply , and surprise is more easily assumed , and not less reasonable than any other . Now let [us]2226-us go on . Were [you]2214-madam never [here]280-here before , [madam]2214-madam ? ”[368-i]

“ Never , [sir]2221-sir . ”[368-i]

“ Indeed ! have [you]2214-madam yet honoured [the Upper Rooms]296-the upper rooms ? ”[368-i]

“ Yes , [sir]2221-sir , [I]368-i was [there]2232-there last Monday . ”[368-i]

“ Have [you]2214-madam been to [the theatre]2218-the theatre ? ”[368-i]

“ Yes , [sir]2221-sir , [I]368-i was at the play on Tuesday . ”[368-i]

“ To the concert ? ”[368-i]

“ Yes , [sir]2221-sir , on Wednesday . ”[368-i]

“ And are [you]2214-madam altogether pleased with [Bath]2236-bath ? ”[368-i]

“ Yes — [I]368-i like it very well . ”[368-i]

“ Now [I]368-i must give one smirk , and then [we]2237-we may be rational again . ”[368-i] [Catherine]73-catherine turned away [her]369-her head , not knowing whether [she]369-her might venture to laugh .

“ [I]370-i see what [you]73-catherine think of [me]370-i , ”[370-i] said [he]370-i gravely—“I shall make but a poor figure in [your]73-catherine journal to - morrow . ”[368-i]

“ [My]368-i journal ! ”[368-i]

“ Yes , [I]368-i know exactly what [you]73-catherine will say : Friday , went to [the Lower Rooms]362-the lower rooms ; wore [my]368-i sprigged muslin robe with blue trimmings — plain black shoes — appeared to much advantage ; but was strangely harassed by [a queer , half - witted man]2239-a queer , half - witted man , who would make [me]368-i dance with [him]370-i , and distressed [me]368-i by [his]370-i nonsense . ”[368-i]

“ Indeed [I]368-i shall say no such thing . ”[368-i]

“ Shall [I]368-i tell [you]73-catherine what [you]73-catherine ought to say ? ”[368-i]

“ If [you]73-catherine please . ”[368-i]

“ [I]368-i danced with [a very agreeable young man]2240-a very agreeable young man , introduced by [Mr. King]91-mr. king ; had a great deal of conversation with [him]2240-a very agreeable young man — seems a most extraordinary genius — hope [I]368-i may know more of [him]2240-a very agreeable young man . _ That _ , [madam]2214-madam , is what [I]368-i _ wish _ [you]2214-madam to say . ”[368-i]

“ But , perhaps , [I]368-i keep no journal . ”[368-i]

“ Perhaps [you]2214-madam are not sitting in [this room]2242-this room , and [I]368-i am not sitting by [you]2214-madam . These are points in which a doubt is equally possible . Not keep a journal ! how are [[your]2214-madam absent cousins]2243-your absent cousins to understand the tenor of [your]2214-madam life in [Bath]5-bath without one ? How are the civilities and compliments of every day to be related as they ought to be , unless noted down every evening in a journal ? How are [your]2214-madam various dresses to be remembered , and the particular state of [your]2214-madam complexion , and curl of [your]2214-madam hair to be described in all [their]2243-your absent cousins diversities , without having constant recourse to a journal ? [[My]368-i dear madam]2244-my dear madam , [I]368-i am not so ignorant of [young ladies]262-young ladies ’ ways as [you]2214-madam wish to believe [me]368-i ; it is this delightful habit of journaling which largely contributes to form the easy style of writing for which [ladies]2246-ladies are so generally celebrated . [Everybody]318-everybody allows that the talent of writing agreeable letters is peculiarly female . Nature may have done something , but [I]368-i am sure it must be essentially assisted by the practice of keeping a journal . ”[368-i]

“ [I]73-catherine have sometimes thought , ”[73-catherine] said [Catherine]73-catherine , doubtingly , “ whether [ladies]2246-ladies do write so much better letters than [gentlemen]2249-gentlemen ! that is — [I]73-catherine should not think the superiority was always on [our]2250-our side . ”[73-catherine]

“ As far as [I]368-i have had opportunity of judging , it appears to [me]368-i that the usual style of letter - writing among [women]2251-women is faultless , except in three particulars . ”[368-i]

“ And what are [they]2246-ladies ? ”[73-catherine]

“ A general deficiency of subject , a total inattention to stops , and a very frequent ignorance of grammar . ”[368-i]

“ Upon [my]73-catherine word ! [i]73-catherine need not have been afraid of disclaiming the compliment . [You]2214-madam do not think too highly of [us]2250-our in that way . ”[73-catherine]

“ [I]368-i should no more lay it down as a general rule that [women]2251-women write better letters than [men]2253-men , than that [they]2251-women sing better duets , or draw better landscapes . In every power , of which taste is the foundation , excellence is pretty fairly divided between the sexes . ”[368-i]

[They]371-they were interrupted by [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen : “ [[My]372-i dear]2185-my dear [Catherine]73-catherine , ”[372-i] said [she]372-i , “ do take this pin out of [my]372-i sleeve ; [I]372-i am afraid it has torn a hole already ; [I]372-i shall be quite sorry if it has , for this is a favourite gown , though it cost but nine shillings a yard . ”[372-i]

“ That is exactly what [I]92-henry should have guessed it , [madam]2214-madam , ”[92-henry] said [Mr. Tilney]92-henry , looking at the muslin .

“ Do [you]2214-madam understand muslins , [sir]2221-sir ? ”[368-i]

“ Particularly well ; [I]372-i always buy [my]372-i own cravats , and am allowed to be [an excellent judge]2257-an excellent judge ; and [[my]372-i sister]2258-my sister has often trusted [me]372-i in the choice of a gown . [I]372-i bought one for [her]2258-my sister the other day , and it was pronounced to be a prodigious bargain by [every lady who saw it]2259-every lady who saw it . [I]372-i gave but five shillings a yard for it , and a true Indian muslin . ”[372-i]

[Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen was quite struck by [his]92-henry genius . “ [Men]2253-men commonly take so little notice of those things , ”[373-she] said [she]373-she ; “ [I]373-she can never get [Mr. Allen]83-mr. allen to know one of [my]373-she gowns from another . [You]83-mr. allen must be a great comfort to [[your]83-mr. allen sister]2261-your sister , [sir]2221-sir . ”[373-she]

“ [I]372-i hope [I]372-i am , [madam]2214-madam . ”[372-i]

“ And pray , [sir]2221-sir , what do [you]2221-sir think of [Miss Morland]84-miss morland ’s gown ? ”[373-she]

“ It is very pretty , [madam]2214-madam , ”[92-henry] said [he]92-henry , gravely examining it ; “ but [I]92-henry do not think it will wash well ; [I]92-henry am afraid it will fray . ”[92-henry]

“ How can [you]92-henry , ”[73-catherine] said [Catherine]73-catherine , laughing , “ be so — ”[73-catherine] [She]373-she had almost said “ strange . ”[373-she]

“ [I]86-mrs. allen am quite of [your]92-henry opinion , [sir]2221-sir , ”[86-mrs. allen] replied [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen ; “ and so [I]86-mrs. allen told [Miss Morland]84-miss morland when [she]84-miss morland bought it . ”[86-mrs. allen]

“ But then [you]2214-madam know , [madam]2214-madam , muslin always turns to some account or other ; [Miss Morland]84-miss morland will get enough out of it for a handkerchief , or a cap , or a cloak . Muslin can never be said to be wasted . [I]92-henry have heard [[my]92-henry sister]2258-my sister say so forty times , when [she]2258-my sister has been extravagant in buying more than [she]2258-my sister wanted , or careless in cutting it to pieces . ”[92-henry]

“ [Bath]2236-bath is [a charming place]2270-a charming place , [sir]2221-sir ; there are so many good shops [here]280-here . [We]2273-we are sadly off in [the country]219-the country ; not but what [we]2273-we have [very good shops in [Salisbury]8-salisbury]2275-very good shops in salisbury , but it is so far to go — eight miles is a long way ; [Mr. Allen]83-mr. allen says it is nine , measured nine ; but [I]374-she am sure it can not be more than eight ; and it is such a fag — [I]374-she come back tired to death . Now , here one can step out of doors and get a thing in five minutes . ”[374-she]

[Mr. Tilney]92-henry was polite enough to seem interested in what [she]374-she said ; and [she]374-she kept [him]92-henry on the subject of muslins till the dancing recommenced . [Catherine]73-catherine feared , as [she]374-she listened to [their]375-they discourse , that [he]92-henry indulged [himself]92-henry a little too much with the foibles of [others]376-others . “ What are [you]73-catherine thinking of so earnestly ? ”[92-henry] said [he]92-henry , as [they]375-they walked back to [the ballroom]300-the ballroom ; “ not of [[your]73-catherine partner]2276-your partner , [I]92-henry hope , for , by that shake of the head , [your]73-catherine meditations are not satisfactory . ”[92-henry]

[Catherine]73-catherine coloured , and said , “ [I]73-catherine was not thinking of anything . ”[73-catherine]

“ That is artful and deep , to be sure ; but [I]73-catherine had rather be told at once that [you]92-henry will not tell [me]73-catherine . ”[73-catherine]

“ Well then , [I]73-catherine will not . ”[73-catherine]

“ Thank [you]92-henry ; for now [we]375-they shall soon be acquainted , as [I]73-catherine am authorized to tease [you]92-henry on this subject whenever [we]375-they meet , and nothing in [the world]191-the world advances intimacy so much . ”[73-catherine]

[They]375-they danced again ; and , when the assembly closed , parted , on [the lady]378-the lady ’s side at least , with a strong inclination for continuing the acquaintance . Whether [she]378-the lady thought of [him]379-he so much , while [she]378-the lady drank [her]378-the lady warm wine and water , and prepared [herself]378-the lady for bed , as to dream of [him]379-he when there , can not be ascertained ; but [I]0-i hope it was no more than in a slight slumber , or a morning doze at most ; for if it be true , as [a celebrated writer]380-a celebrated writer has maintained , that [no young lady]381-no young lady can be justified in falling in love before [the gentleman]382-the gentleman ’s love is declared,[1 ] it must be very improper that [a young lady]241-a young lady should dream of [a gentleman]384-a gentleman before [the gentleman]382-the gentleman is first known to have dreamt of [her]241-a young lady . How proper [Mr. Tilney]92-henry might be as [a dreamer]386-a dreamer or [a lover]387-a lover had not yet perhaps entered [Mr. Allen]83-mr. allen ’s head , but that [he]379-he was not objectionable as a common acquaintance for [[his]379-he young charge]388-his young charge [he]379-he was on inquiry satisfied ; for [he]379-he had early in the evening taken pains to know who [[her]241-a young lady partner]389-her partner was , and had been assured of [Mr. Tilney]92-henry ’s being [a clergyman]185-a clergyman , and of [a very respectable family in [Gloucestershire]9-gloucestershire]391-a very respectable family in gloucestershire .

[ 1 ] Vide a letter from [Mr. Richardson]93-mr. richardson , No . 97 , Vol . ii , [Rambler]94-rambler .

CHAPTER 4

With more than usual eagerness did [Catherine]73-catherine hasten to [the pump - room]357-the pump - room the next day , secure within [herself]73-catherine of seeing [Mr. Tilney]92-henry [there]2232-there before the morning were over , and ready to meet [him]92-henry with a smile ; but no smile was demanded — [Mr. Tilney]92-henry did not appear . [Every creature in [Bath]2236-bath]394-every creature in bath , except [himself]92-henry , was to be seen in [the room]301-the room at different periods of the fashionable hours ; [crowds of people]397-crowds of people were every moment passing in and out , up the steps and down ; people whom [nobody cared about]398-nobody cared about , and [nobody wanted to see]399-nobody wanted to see ; and [he]92-henry only was absent . “ What [a delightful place Bath]2278-a delightful place bath is , ”[86-mrs. allen] said [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen as [they]400-we sat down near the great clock , after parading [the room]301-the room till [they]400-we were tired ; “ and how pleasant it would be if [we]400-we had any acquaintance [here]280-here . ”[86-mrs. allen]

This sentiment had been uttered so often in vain that [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen had no particular reason to hope it would be followed with more advantage now ; but [we]400-we are told to “ despair of nothing [we]400-we would attain , ”[403-a lady of about her own age] as “ unwearied diligence [our]400-we point would gain ”[403-a lady of about her own age] ; and the unwearied diligence with which [she]402-her had every day wished for the same thing was at length to have its just reward , for hardly had [she]402-her been seated ten minutes before [a lady of about [her]402-her own age]403-a lady of about her own age , who was sitting by [her]402-her , and had been looking at [her]402-her attentively for several minutes , addressed [her]402-her with great complaisance in these words : “ [I]403-a lady of about her own age think , [madam]2214-madam , [I]403-a lady of about her own age can not be mistaken ; it is a long time since [I]403-a lady of about her own age had the pleasure of seeing [you]402-her , but is not [your]402-her name [Allen]86-mrs. allen ? ”[403-a lady of about her own age] This question answered , as it readily was , [the stranger]404-the stranger pronounced [hers]402-her to be [Thorpe]95-miss thorpe ; and [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen immediately recognized the features of [a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom [she]402-her had seen only once since [their]406-their respective marriages]405-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages , and that many years ago . [Their]406-their joy on this meeting was very great , as well it might , since [they]406-their had been contented to know nothing of [each other]330-each other for the last fifteen years . Compliments on good looks now passed ; and , after observing how time had slipped away since [they]406-their were last together , how little [they]406-their had thought of meeting in [Bath]5-bath , and what a pleasure it was to see [an old friend]408-an old friend , [they]406-their proceeded to make inquiries and give intelligence as to [[their]406-their families]409-their families , [sisters]410-sisters , and [cousins]411-cousins , talking both together , far more ready to give than to receive information , and each hearing very little of what [the other]412-the other said . [Mrs. Thorpe]96-mrs. thorpe , however , had one great advantage as [a talker]413-a talker , over [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen , in [a family of children]414-a family of children ; and when [she]96-mrs. thorpe expatiated on the talents of [[her]96-mrs. thorpe sons]415-her sons , and the beauty of [[her]96-mrs. thorpe daughters]202-her daughters , when [she]96-mrs. thorpe related [their]406-their different situations and views — that [John]97-john was at [Oxford]10-oxford , [Edward]98-edward at [Merchant Taylors]99-merchant taylors ’ , and [William]100-william at [sea]417-sea — and all of [them]406-their more beloved and respected in [their]406-their different station than [any other three beings ever were]418-any other three beings ever were , [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen had no similar information to give , no similar triumphs to press on the unwilling and unbelieving ear of [[her]96-mrs. thorpe friend]305-her friend , and was forced to sit and appear to listen to all these maternal effusions , consoling [herself]86-mrs. allen , however , with the discovery , which [her]96-mrs. thorpe keen eyes soon made , that the lace on [Mrs. Thorpe]96-mrs. thorpe ’s pelisse was not half so handsome as that on [her]96-mrs. thorpe own .

“ Here come [[my]96-mrs. thorpe dear girls]2281-my dear girls , ”[96-mrs. thorpe] cried [Mrs. Thorpe]96-mrs. thorpe , pointing at [three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards [her]96-mrs. thorpe]420-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her . “ [[My]96-mrs. thorpe dear]2185-my dear [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen , [I]96-mrs. thorpe long to introduce [them]420-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her ; [they]420-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her will be so delighted to see [you]2185-my dear : [the tallest]2283-the tallest is [Isabella]101-isabella , [[my]96-mrs. thorpe eldest]2284-my eldest ; is not [she]101-isabella [a fine young woman]2285-a fine young woman ? [The others]2286-the others are very much admired too , but [I]96-mrs. thorpe believe [Isabella]101-isabella is the handsomest . ”[96-mrs. thorpe]

[The Miss Thorpes]102-the thorpes were introduced ; and [Miss Morland]84-miss morland , who had been for a short time forgotten , was introduced likewise . The name seemed to strike [them]421-their all ; and , after speaking to [her]84-miss morland with great civility , [the eldest young lady]422-the eldest young lady observed aloud to [the rest]319-the rest , “ How excessively like [[her]422-the eldest young lady brother]2287-her brother [Miss Morland]84-miss morland is ! ”[422-the eldest young lady]

“ The very picture of [him]2287-her brother indeed ! ”[424-the mother] cried [the mother]424-the mother — and “ [I]424-the mother should have known [her]2287-her brother anywhere for [[his]2287-her brother sister]2288-his sister ! ”[424-the mother] was repeated by [them]421-their all , two or three times over . For a moment [Catherine]73-catherine was surprised ; but [Mrs. Thorpe]96-mrs. thorpe and [[her]96-mrs. thorpe daughters]202-her daughters had scarcely begun the history of [their]421-their acquaintance with [Mr. James Morland]103-james , before [she]96-mrs. thorpe remembered that [[her]96-mrs. thorpe eldest brother]426-her eldest brother had lately formed an intimacy with [a young man of [[his]426-her eldest brother own college]428-his own college , of the name of [Thorpe]96-mrs. thorpe]427-a young man of his own college , of the name of thorpe ; and that [he]426-her eldest brother had spent the last week of the Christmas vacation with [[his]426-her eldest brother family]429-his family , near [London]11-london .

The whole being explained , many obliging things were said by [the Miss Thorpes]102-the thorpes of [their]421-their wish of being better acquainted with [her]96-mrs. thorpe ; of being considered as [already friends]430-already friends , through the friendship of [[their]421-their brothers]431-their brothers , etc . , which [Catherine]73-catherine heard with pleasure , and answered with all the pretty expressions [she]96-mrs. thorpe could command ; and , as the first proof of amity , [she]96-mrs. thorpe was soon invited to accept an arm of [the eldest Miss Thorpe]95-miss thorpe , and take a turn with [her]95-miss thorpe about [the room]301-the room . [Catherine]73-catherine was delighted with this extension of [her]96-mrs. thorpe Bath acquaintance , and almost forgot [Mr. Tilney]92-henry while [she]96-mrs. thorpe talked to [Miss Thorpe]95-miss thorpe . Friendship is certainly the finest balm for the pangs of disappointed love .

[Their]421-their conversation turned upon those subjects , of which the free discussion has generally much to do in perfecting a sudden intimacy between [two young ladies]433-two young ladies : such as dress , balls , flirtations , and quizzes . [Miss Thorpe]95-miss thorpe , however , being four years older than [Miss Morland]84-miss morland , and at least four years better informed , had a very decided advantage in discussing such points ; [she]95-miss thorpe could compare the balls of Bath with those of [Tunbridge]12-tunbridge , its fashions with the fashions of [London]11-london ; could rectify the opinions of [[her]95-miss thorpe new friend]434-her new friend in many articles of tasteful attire ; could discover a flirtation between [any gentleman]435-any gentleman and [lady who only smiled on each other]436-lady who only smiled on each other ; and point out a quiz through the thickness of [a crowd]437-a crowd . These powers received due admiration from [Catherine]73-catherine , to whom [they]421-their were entirely new ; and the respect which [they]421-their naturally inspired might have been too great for familiarity , had not the easy gaiety of [Miss Thorpe]95-miss thorpe ’s manners , and [her]95-miss thorpe frequent expressions of delight on this acquaintance with [her]95-miss thorpe , softened down every feeling of awe , and left nothing but tender affection . [Their]421-their increasing attachment was not to be satisfied with half a dozen turns in [the pump - room]357-the pump - room , but required , when [they]421-their all quitted it together , that [Miss Thorpe]95-miss thorpe should accompany [Miss Morland]84-miss morland to the very door of [[Mr. Allen]83-mr. allen ’s house]439-mr. allen ’s house ; and that [they]421-their should there part with a most affectionate and lengthened shake of hands , after learning , to [their]421-their mutual relief , that [they]421-their should see [each other]330-each other across [the theatre]2218-the theatre at night , and say [their]421-their prayers in [the same chapel]442-the same chapel the next morning . [Catherine]73-catherine then ran directly [upstairs]443-upstairs , and watched [Miss Thorpe]95-miss thorpe ’s progress down [the street]444-the street from [the drawing - room]445-the drawing - room window ; admired the graceful spirit of [her]95-miss thorpe walk , the fashionable air of [her]95-miss thorpe figure and dress ; and felt grateful , as well [she]95-miss thorpe might , for the chance which had procured [her]95-miss thorpe such [a friend]446-a friend .

[Mrs. Thorpe]96-mrs. thorpe was [a widow]447-a widow , and [not a very rich one]448-not a very rich one ; [she]96-mrs. thorpe was [a good - humoured , well - meaning woman]449-a good - humoured , well - meaning woman , and [a very indulgent mother]450-a very indulgent mother . [[Her]96-mrs. thorpe eldest daughter]451-her eldest daughter had great personal beauty , and [the younger ones]452-the younger ones , by pretending to be as handsome as [[their]452-the younger ones sister]453-their sister , imitating [her]95-miss thorpe air , and dressing in the same style , did very well .

This brief account of [the family]454-the family is intended to supersede the necessity of a long and minute detail from [Mrs. Thorpe]96-mrs. thorpe [herself]96-mrs. thorpe , of [her]96-mrs. thorpe past adventures and sufferings , which might otherwise be expected to occupy the three or four following chapters ; in which the worthlessness of [lords]264-lords and [attorneys]456-attorneys might be set forth , and conversations , which had passed twenty years before , be minutely repeated .

CHAPTER 5

[Catherine]73-catherine was not so much engaged at [the theatre]2218-the theatre that evening , in returning the nods and smiles of [Miss Thorpe]95-miss thorpe , though [they]458-they certainly claimed much of [her]96-mrs. thorpe leisure , as to forget to look with an inquiring eye for [Mr. Tilney]92-henry in every box which [her]96-mrs. thorpe eye could reach ; but [she]96-mrs. thorpe looked in vain . [Mr. Tilney]92-henry was no fonder of the play than [the pump - room]357-the pump - room . [She]96-mrs. thorpe hoped to be more fortunate the next day ; and when [her]96-mrs. thorpe wishes for fine weather were answered by seeing a beautiful morning , [she]96-mrs. thorpe hardly felt a doubt of it ; for a fine Sunday in Bath empties [every house of [its]460-every house of its inhabitants inhabitants]460-every house of its inhabitants , and all [the world]191-the world appears on such an occasion to walk about and tell [their]462-they acquaintance what a charming day it is .

As soon as divine service was over , [the Thorpes]102-the thorpes and [Allens]104-the allens eagerly joined [each other]330-each other ; and after staying long enough in [the pump - room]357-the pump - room to discover that [the crowd]298-the crowd was insupportable , and that there was not a genteel face to be seen , which [everybody]318-everybody discovers every Sunday throughout the season , [they]462-they hastened away to [the Crescent]13-the crescent , to breathe the fresh air of better company . Here [Catherine]73-catherine and [Isabella]101-isabella , arm in arm , again tasted the sweets of friendship in an unreserved conversation ; [they]462-they talked much , and with much enjoyment ; but again was [Catherine]73-catherine disappointed in [her]96-mrs. thorpe hope of reseeing [[her]96-mrs. thorpe partner]389-her partner . [He]389-her partner was nowhere to be met with ; every search for [him]389-her partner was equally unsuccessful , in morning lounges or evening assemblies ; neither at [the Upper nor Lower Rooms]468-the upper nor lower rooms , at dressed or undressed balls , was [he]389-her partner perceivable ; nor among [the walkers]469-the walkers , [the horsemen]470-the horsemen , or [the curricle - drivers of the morning]471-the curricle - drivers of the morning . [His]389-her partner name was not in the pump - room book , and curiosity could do no more . [He]389-her partner must be gone from [Bath]5-bath . Yet [he]389-her partner had not mentioned that [his]389-her partner stay would be so short ! this sort of mysteriousness , which is always so becoming in [a hero]244-a hero , threw a fresh grace in [Catherine]73-catherine ’s imagination around [his]389-her partner person and manners , and increased [her]96-mrs. thorpe anxiety to know more of [him]389-her partner . From [the Thorpes]102-the thorpes [she]96-mrs. thorpe could learn nothing , for [they]102-the thorpes had been only two days in [Bath]5-bath before [they]102-the thorpes met with [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen . It was a subject , however , in which [she]96-mrs. thorpe often indulged with [[her]96-mrs. thorpe fair friend]473-her fair friend , from whom [she]96-mrs. thorpe received every possible encouragement to continue to think of [him]389-her partner ; and [his]389-her partner impression on [her]96-mrs. thorpe fancy was not suffered therefore to weaken . [Isabella]101-isabella was very sure that [he]389-her partner must be [a charming young man]474-a charming young man , and was equally sure that [he]389-her partner must have been delighted with [[her]96-mrs. thorpe dear]475-her dear [Catherine]73-catherine , and would therefore shortly return . [She]101-isabella liked [him]389-her partner the better for being [a clergyman]185-a clergyman , “ for [she]101-isabella must confess [herself]101-isabella very partial to the profession ”[101-isabella] ; and something like a sigh escaped [her]101-isabella as [she]101-isabella said it . Perhaps [Catherine]73-catherine was wrong in not demanding the cause of that gentle emotion — but [she]96-mrs. thorpe was not experienced enough in the finesse of love , or the duties of friendship , to know when delicate raillery was properly called for , or when a confidence should be forced .

[Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen was now quite happy — quite satisfied with Bath . [She]96-mrs. thorpe had found [some acquaintance]477-some acquaintance , had been so lucky too as to find in [them]477-some acquaintance [the family of [a most worthy old friend]479-a most worthy old friend]478-the family of a most worthy old friend ; and , as the completion of good fortune , had found [these friends]480-these friends by no means so expensively dressed as [herself]96-mrs. thorpe . [Her]96-mrs. thorpe daily expressions were no longer , “ [I]481-i wish [we]2289-we had some acquaintance in [Bath]5-bath ! ”[481-i] [They]481-i were changed into , “ How glad [I]96-mrs. thorpe am [we]2289-we have met with [Mrs. Thorpe]96-mrs. thorpe ! ”[96-mrs. thorpe] and [she]96-mrs. thorpe was as eager in promoting the intercourse of [the two families]482-the two families , as [[her]96-mrs. thorpe young charge]483-her young charge and [Isabella]101-isabella [themselves]482-the two families could be ; never satisfied with the day unless [she]96-mrs. thorpe spent the chief of it by the side of [Mrs. Thorpe]96-mrs. thorpe , in what [they]482-the two families called conversation , but in which there was scarcely ever any exchange of opinion , and not often any resemblance of subject , for [Mrs. Thorpe]96-mrs. thorpe talked chiefly of [[her]96-mrs. thorpe children]216-her children , and [Mrs. Allen]86-mrs. allen of [her]96-mrs. thorpe gowns .

The progress of the friendship between [Catherine]73-catherine and [Isabella]101-isabella was quick as its beginning had been warm , and [they]482-the two families passed so rapidly through every gradation of increasing tenderness that there was shortly no fresh proof of it to be given to [[their]482-the two families friends]485-their friends or [themselves]482-the two families . [They]482-the two families called [each other]330-each other by [their]482-the two families Christian name , were always arm in arm when [they]482-the two families walked , pinned up [each other]330-each other ’s train for the dance , and were not to be divided in the set ; and if a rainy morning deprived [them]482-the two families of other enjoyments , [they]482-the two families were still resolute in meeting in defiance of wet and dirt , and shut [themselves]482-the two families up , to read novels together . Yes , novels ; for [I]0-i will not adopt that ungenerous and impolitic custom so common with [novel - writers]488-novel - writers , of degrading by [their]488-novel - writers contemptuous censure the very performances , to the number of which [they]488-novel - writers are [themselves]488-novel - writers adding — joining with [[their]488-novel - writers greatest enemies]489-their greatest enemies in bestowing the harshest epithets on such works , and scarcely ever permitting [them]488-novel - writers to be read by [[their]488-novel - writers own heroine]490-their own heroine , who , if [she]490-their own heroine accidentally take up a novel , is sure to turn over its insipid pages with disgust . Alas ! if [the heroine of one novel]491-the heroine of one novel be not patronized by [the heroine of another]492-the heroine of another , from whom can [she]490-their own heroine expect protection and regard ? [I]0-i can not approve of it . Let [us]493-our leave it to [the reviewers]494-the reviewers to abuse such effusions of fancy at [their]494-the reviewers leisure , and over every new novel to talk in threadbare strains of the trash with which the press now groans . Let [us]493-our not desert [one another]495-one another ; [we]493-our are [an injured body]496-an injured body . Although [our]493-our productions have afforded more extensive and unaffected pleasure than those of any other literary corporation in [the world]191-the world , no species of composition has been so much decried . From pride , ignorance , or fashion , [[our]493-our foes]498-our foes are almost as many as [[our]493-our readers]499-our readers . And while the abilities of the nine - hundredth abridger of the History of [England]2-england , or of [the man who collects and publishes in a volume some dozen lines of Milton , Pope]500-the man who collects and publishes in a volume some dozen lines of milton , pope , and Prior , with a paper from the Spectator , and a chapter from [Sterne]105-sterne , are eulogized by a thousand pens — there seems almost a general wish of decrying the capacity and undervaluing the labour of [the novelist , and of slighting the performances which have only genius , wit , and taste to recommend them]501-the novelist , and of slighting the performances which have only genius , wit , and taste to recommend them . “ [I]105-sterne am [no novel - reader]2290-no novel - reader — [I]105-sterne seldom look into novels — Do not imagine that _ [I]105-sterne _ often read novels — It is really very well for a novel . ”[105-sterne] Such is the common ca nt . “ And what are [you]504-the same young lady reading , [Miss]2291-miss — — ? ”[105-sterne] “ Oh ! it is only a novel ! ”[502-the young lady] replies [the young lady]502-the young lady , while [she]502-the young lady lays down [her]502-the young lady book with affected indifference , or momentary shame . “ It is only [Cecilia]106-cecilia , or [Camilla]107-camilla , or [Belinda]108-isabella ”[502-the young lady] ; or , in short , only some work in which the greatest powers of the mind are displayed , in which the most thorough knowledge of human nature , the happiest delineation of its varieties , the liveliest effusions of wit and humour , are conveyed to [the world]191-the world in the best - chosen language . Now , had [the same young lady]504-the same young lady been engaged with a volume of [the Spectator]505-the spectator , instead of such a work , how proudly would [she]504-the same young lady have produced the book , and told its name ; though the chances must be against [her]502-the young lady being occupied by any part of that voluminous publication , of which either the matter or manner would not disgust [a young person of taste]506-a young person of taste : the substance of its papers so often consisting in the statement of improbable circumstances , unnatural characters , and topics of conversation which no longer concern [anyone living]507-anyone living ; and [their]508-their language , too , frequently so coarse as to give no very favourable idea of the age that could endure it .

CHAPTER 6

The following conversation , which took place between [the two friends]509-the two friends in [the pump - room]357-the pump - room one morning , after [an acquaintance of eight or nine days]511-an acquaintance of eight or nine days , is given as a specimen of [their]509-the two friends very warm attachment , and of the delicacy , discretion , originality of thought , and literary taste which marked the reasonableness of that attachment .

[They]509-the two friends met by appointment ; and as [Isabella]108-isabella had arrived nearly five minutes before [[her]108-isabella friend]305-her friend , [her]108-isabella first address naturally was , “ [[My]108-isabella dearest]2292-my dearest creature , what can have made [you]2292-my dearest so late ? [I]108-isabella have been waiting for [you]2292-my dearest at least this age ! ”[108-isabella]

“ Have [you]2292-my dearest , indeed ! [i]108-isabella am very sorry for it ; but really [I]108-isabella thought [I]108-isabella was in very good time . It is but just one . [I]108-isabella hope [you]2292-my dearest have not been [here]280-here long ? ”[108-isabella]

“ Oh ! these ten ages at least . [I]108-isabella am sure [I]108-isabella have been [here]280-here this half hour . But now , let [us]509-the two friends go and sit down at the other end of [the room]301-the room , and enjoy [ourselves]509-the two friends . [I]108-isabella have an hundred things to say to [you]2292-my dearest . In the first place , [I]108-isabella was so afraid it would rain this morning , just as [I]108-isabella wanted to set off ; it looked very showery , and that would have thrown [me]108-isabella into agonies ! do [you]2292-my dearest know , [I]108-isabella saw the prettiest hat [you]2292-my dearest can imagine , in a shop window in [Milsom Street]14-milsom street just now — very like [yours]2292-my dearest , only with coquelicot ribbons instead of green ; [I]108-isabella quite longed for it . But , [[my]108-isabella dearest]2292-my dearest [Catherine]73-catherine , what have [you]2292-my dearest been doing with [yourself]2292-my dearest all this morning ? Have [you]2292-my dearest gone on with [Udolpho]109-udolpho ? ”[108-isabella]

“ Yes , [I]108-isabella have been reading it ever since [I]108-isabella woke ; and [I]108-isabella am got to the black veil . ”[108-isabella]

“ Are [you]2292-my dearest , indeed ? How delightful ! oh ! [i]108-isabella would not tell [you]2292-my dearest what is behind the black veil for [the world]191-the world ! are not [you]2292-my dearest wild to know ? ”[108-isabella]

“ Oh ! yes , quite ; what can it be ? But do not tell [me]108-isabella — [I]108-isabella would not be told upon any account . [I]108-isabella know it must be a skeleton , [I]108-isabella am sure it is [Laurentina]110-laurentina ’s skeleton . Oh ! [i]108-isabella am delighted with the book ! [i]108-isabella should like to spend [my]108-isabella whole life in reading it . [I]108-isabella assure [you]2292-my dearest , if it had not been to meet [you]2292-my dearest , [I]108-isabella would not have come away from it for all [the world]191-the world . ”[108-isabella]

“ [Dear creature]2299-dear creature ! how much [I]108-isabella am obliged to [you]2292-my dearest ; and when [you]2292-my dearest have finished [Udolpho]109-udolpho , [we]2300-we will read the Italian together ; and [I]108-isabella have made out a list of ten or twelve more of the same kind for [you]2292-my dearest . ”[108-isabella]

“ Have [you]2292-my dearest , indeed ! how glad [I]108-isabella am ! what are [they]2301-they all ? ”[108-isabella]

“ [I]108-isabella will read [you]2292-my dearest [their]2301-they names directly ; here they are , in [my]108-isabella pocketbook . [Castle of [Wolfenbach]15-wolfenbach]2302-castle of wolfenbach , [Clermont]16-clermont , [Mysterious Warnings]111-mysterious warnings , Necromancer of [the Black Forest]17-the black forest , [Midnight Bell]108-isabella , Orphan of [the Rhine]18-the rhine , and Horrid Mysteries . Those will last [us]2300-we some time . ”[108-isabella]

“ Yes , pretty well ; but are [they]2301-they all horrid , are [you]2292-my dearest sure [they]2301-they are all horrid ? ”[108-isabella]

“ Yes , quite sure ; for [a particular friend of [mine]108-isabella]2303-a particular friend of mine , a [Miss Andrews]112-miss andrews , [a sweet girl]2304-a sweet girl , [one of the sweetest creatures in [the world]191-the world]2305-one of the sweetest creatures in the world , has read every one of [them]2301-they . [I]108-isabella wish [you]2292-my dearest knew [Miss Andrews]112-miss andrews , [you]2292-my dearest would be delighted with [her]112-miss andrews . [She]112-miss andrews is netting [herself]112-miss andrews the sweetest cloak [you]2292-my dearest can conceive . [I]108-isabella think [her]112-miss andrews as beautiful as [an angel]2307-an angel , and [I]108-isabella am so vexed with [the men]2308-the men for not admiring [her]112-miss andrews ! [i]108-isabella scold [them]2308-the men all amazingly about it . ”[108-isabella]

“ Scold [them]2308-the men ! do [you]108-isabella scold [them]2308-the men for not admiring [her]112-miss andrews ? ”[108-isabella]

“ Yes , that [I]108-isabella do . There is nothing [I]108-isabella would not do for [those who are really [[my]108-isabella friends]2310-my friends]2309-those who are really my friends . [I]108-isabella have no notion of loving [people]320-people by halves ; it is not [my]108-isabella nature . [My]108-isabella attachments are always excessively strong . [I]108-isabella told [Captain Hunt]113-captain hunt at one of [[our]2312-our assemblies]2313-our assemblies this winter that if [he]113-captain hunt was to tease [me]108-isabella all night , [I]108-isabella would not dance with [him]113-captain hunt , unless [he]113-captain hunt would allow [Miss Andrews]112-miss andrews to be as beautiful as [an angel]2307-an angel . [The men]2308-the men think [us]2312-our incapable of real friendship , [you]2316-you know , and [I]108-isabella am determined to show [them]2308-the men the difference . Now , if [I]108-isabella were to hear [anybody]192-anybody speak slightingly of [you]2316-you , [I]108-isabella should fire up in a moment : but that is not at all likely , for _ [you]2316-you _ are just [the kind of girl]2318-the kind of girl to be a great favourite with [the men]2308-the men . ”[108-isabella]

“ Oh , [dear]2320-dear ! ”[73-catherine] cried [Catherine]73-catherine , colouring . “ How can [you]2320-dear say so ? ”[73-catherine]

“ [I]73-catherine know [you]2316-you very well ; [you]2316-you have so much animation , which is exactly what [Miss Andrews]112-miss andrews wants , for [I]73-catherine must confess there is something amazingly insipid about [her]112-miss andrews . Oh ! [i]73-catherine must tell [you]2316-you , that just after [we]2321-we parted yesterday , [I]73-catherine saw [a young man]2322-a young man looking at [you]2316-you so earnestly — [I]73-catherine am sure [he]2322-a young man is in love with [you]2316-you . ”[73-catherine] [Catherine]73-catherine coloured , and disclaimed again . [Isabella]108-isabella laughed . “ It is very true , upon [my]108-isabella honour , but [I]108-isabella see how it is ; [you]2316-you are indifferent to [everybody]318-everybody ’s admiration , except that of [one gentleman]2324-one gentleman , who shall be nameless . Nay , [I]108-isabella can not blame you”—speaking[108-isabella] more seriously—“your feelings are easily understood . Where the heart is really attached , [I]73-catherine know very well how little one can be pleased with the attention of [anybody else]2325-anybody else . “ But [you]2316-you should not persuade [me]108-isabella that [I]108-isabella think so very much about [Mr. Tilney]92-henry , for perhaps [I]108-isabella may never see [him]92-henry again . ”[108-isabella]

“ Not see [him]92-henry again ! [[my]73-catherine dearest]2292-my dearest creature , do not talk of it . [I]73-catherine am sure [you]2316-you would be miserable if [you]2316-you thought so ! ”[73-catherine]

“ No , indeed , [I]108-isabella should not . “ [Sir Charles Grandison]114-sir charles grandison ! that is an amazing horrid book , is it not ? [I]73-catherine remember [Miss Andrews]112-miss andrews could not get through the first volume . ”[73-catherine]

“ It is not like [Udolpho]109-udolpho at all ; but yet [I]108-isabella think it is very entertaining . ”[108-isabella]

“ Do [you]2316-you indeed ! [you]2316-you surprise [me]73-catherine ; [I]73-catherine thought it had not been readable . “ But it does not signify if [they]2308-the men do , ”[73-catherine] said [Catherine]73-catherine , very innocently .

“ Signify ! oh , heavens ! [i]73-catherine make it a rule never to mind what [they]2308-the men say . “ Are [they]2308-the men ? Well , [I]73-catherine never observed _ that _ . [They]2308-the men always behave very well to [me]73-catherine . ”[73-catherine]

“ Oh ! [they]2308-the men give [themselves]2308-the men such airs . [They]2308-the men are [the most conceited creatures in [the world]191-the world]2333-the most conceited creatures in the world , and think [themselves]2308-the men of so much importance ! by the by , though [I]73-catherine have thought of it a hundred times , [I]73-catherine have always forgot to ask [you]73-catherine what is [your]73-catherine favourite complexion in [a man]2335-a man .
